newsitem.title: MOZAMBIQUE: Mozambique beats IMF 1996 inflation target.
newsitem.headline: Mozambique beats IMF 1996 inflation target.

text.p: Mozambique has easily beaten the International Monetary Fund's 1996 inflation target of 22 percent, official figures released by the National Statistics Board (NSB) showed on Thursday.
The state-owned news agency reported that the average inflation rate for the country's three biggest cities -- usually a reliable indicator for national trends -- stood at 16.96 percent.
The board said inflation was 15.3 percent in the capital Maputo, 16.6 percent in Beira and 19 percent in northern Nampula.
Mozambique's President Joaquim Chissano, in talks with the IMF in 1995, accepted a target inflation figure of 22 percent for 1996.
The fund announced in June 1996 a three-year loan of $109 million to help the slow recovery from a 16-year civil war.
The actual inflation figure is the lowest since the current method of calculating the consumer price index was introduced in 1989. Inflation in 1995 was 54.1 percent and 70.2 percent in 1994.
Economists in Maputo said a good harvest in 1996 and the devaluation of the rand helped to keep prices down. Cereal harvests last year reached a record 1.37 million tonnes.

In 1996, the Mozambican currency, the metical, was more stable than the rand. The fall in the rand cut the price of importing goods from neighbouring South Africa which provides 60 percent of all imports.
Restrictive monetary policy implemented by Mozambique's central bank also helped to push down prices, the economists said, adding that limits on credit and money supply had been maintained.
